review.title: Local Optimal Sets and Bounded Archiving on Multi-objective NK-Landscapes with Correlated Objectives
review.abstract: The properties of local optimal solutions in multi-objective combinatorial optimization problems are crucial for the effectiveness of local search algorithms, particularly when these algorithms are based on Pareto dominance. Such local search algorithms typically return a set of mutually nondominated Pareto local optimal (PLO) solutions, that is, a PLO-set. This paper investigates two aspects of PLO-sets by means of experiments with Pareto local search (PLS). First, we examine the impact of several problem characteristics on the properties of PLO-sets for multi-objective NK-landscapes with correlated objectives. In particular, we report that either increasing the number of objectives or decreasing the correlation between objectives leads to an exponential increment on the size of PLO-sets, whereas the variable correlation has only a minor effect. Second, we study the running time and the quality reached when using bounding archiving methods to limit the size of the archive handled by PLS, and thus, the maximum size of the PLO-set found. We argue that there is a clear relationship between the running time of PLS and the difficulty of a problem instance.
histories: appears in Parallel Problem Solving from Nature - PPSN XIII, Ljubljana : Slovenia (2014)
review.COMMENTS: appears in Parallel Problem Solving from Nature - PPSN XIII, Ljubljana : Slovenia (2014)

metadata.title: Local Optimal Sets and Bounded Archiving on Multi-objective NK-Landscapes with Correlated Objectives

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Several state-of-the-art algorithms for multi-objective combinatorial optimization problems (MCOPs) are based on local search. These local search algorithms are either based on solving multiple scalarizations of the objective function vector, or they are based on Pareto dominance. The most successful local search algorithms combine both approaches [3,4,10,13]. These successes explain the growing interest in understanding the role of local optimal solutions in the context of MCOPs. Previous work has focused on the characteristics of individual local optimal solutions [14]. However, algorithms for MCOPs typically do not lead to a single solution, but to a number of solutions that approach the Pareto set. Thus, local search algorithms for MCOPs are typically affected by (Pareto) local optimal sets (PLO sets), that is, sets of (Pareto) optimal solutions are also related to the PLI 1957 Xiv 9.19].

sections.heading: 3 Experimental Setup
sections.text: In the following, we examine the neighborhood structure as a 1-bit flip. The archive starts with a random solution of the problem, which corresponds to a random effect on each of the three selected neighborhood solutions. In the following, we cover the three selected PLLS solutions, selecting the epistatic degree k (1, 2, 4, 8) so that k < n, an objective spatial dimension m (2, 3, 5) and an objective correlation (0.7, -0.2, 0.2, 0.7) so that the corresponding correlation matrix is symmetrically positively defined. [14] The problem sizes investigated allow us to exhaustively enumerate the solution space and then optimally resolve all instances. For each parameter combination, an independent random instance is taken into account: < ρ, m, n, k >. This results in a total of 91 problem instances. In our implementation of PLS for the PLLS landscapes, the neighborhood structure is taken as a neighborhood flip-1.

sections.heading: 4 Experimental Analysis
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Cardinality of Pareto Local Optimal Sets
sections.text: Figure 1 shows the size of the PLO sets identified by PLSunb with respect to different instance characteristics. Each point indicates the mean over the 25 random seeds of the same instance, and the error bars indicate the standard deviation. PLO sets are plotted on a logarithmic scale. Generally, the cardinality of PLO sets increases exponentially with the number of targets m, as shown in Fig. 1a-1c. Correlation between the objective values ρ is also a decisive factor: the cardinality of PLO sets increases exponentially with the linear decrease of ρ (Fig. 1c). The cardinality of PLO sets also increases with lower k, but much less clearly (Fig. 1a). Furthermore, the small error bars in Fig. 1a-1d indicate that for a given case maximum PLO sets consistently exhibit approximately the same size, but with much less clarity (Fig. 1a).

sections.heading: 4.2 Quality of Local Optimal Sets
sections.text: We examine the quality of the PLO sets found by PLSunb, PLShva and PLSmga using two simple quality measures, namely the hypervolume and the multiplicative epsilon [15]. To compare the hypervolume value for cases with very different characteristics, we calculate the relative difference of the hypervolume as hvr (A) = (hv (P) − hv (P), where A Z is the image of a PLO set in objective space and P is the exact Pareto front for the instance under consideration. Thus, the reference point is determined at the origin. The Epsilon measure specifies the minimum multiplication factor around which a PLO set must be shifted in objective space to weakly dominate the exact Pareto front. Thus, a lower value in relation to volume is preferred for both measurements.

sections.heading: 4.3 Difficulty of Identifying Local Optimal Sets
sections.text: Indeed, the longer the process takes, the larger it becomes, the larger it becomes, and the larger the number of local optimists.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we analyzed the characteristics of local optima in the context of a multi-objective local search when applied to multi-objective NK landscapes with correlated targets. Firstly, the main factors influencing the cardinality of the maximum PLO sets returned by PLSunb are the number of targets and the correlation between them. By altering these two factors, the size of PLO sets may vary from a few tens to tens of thousands. Our results confirm trends that have already been observed for other MCOP problems. In particular, the exponential increase in PLO sets with lower objective correlation has already been reported for the bi-objective QAP sets [13]. Another interesting observation is that the variability of PLO sets is usually a very small fraction of the average size of PLO sets, i.e. most maximum PLO sets for a given instance have approximately the same size of PLO sets as we do not know at present, and other PLO sets do not.

Experimental studies on PLO-sets have been so far limited to the study of some of their properties for the bi-objective traveling salesman problem, in particular the number of solutions in each PLO-set and the connectedness of PLOsets [11].

First, we consider multi-objective NK-landscapes with correlated objectives (ρMNKlandscapes) [14], which allow us to examine the effect of various problem characteristics on the properties of PLO-sets.
Second, we examine the effect of using bounded archiving methods [7,9] in order to limit the size of the PLO-set handled by the local search.
Second, we examine the effect of using bounded archiving methods [7,9] in order to limit the size of the PLO-set handled by the local search.
Archiving methods are often used in both local search and evolutionary multi-objective algorithms, and there are a few recent works on their theoretical properties [2,8,9].

A set S ⊆ X is a Pareto local optimal set (PLO-set) with respect to N if, and only if, it contains only PLO-solutions with respect to N and all solutions are mutually nondominated [12].
In addition, a set S ⊆ X is a maximal PLO-set with respect to N if, and only if, ∀s′ ∈ N (S), ∃s ∈ S such that s ≺ s′ ∨ f(s) = f(s′), where N (S) = ⋃ s∈S N (s) [12].
A typical example of a multi-objective local search algorithm is Pareto Local Search (PLS) [12].
PLS is known to be a well-performing algorithm, either as a stand-alone approach or as a hybrid component, for many MCOPs [3,4,10,13].

Moreover, independently of the initial archive, PLS always terminates and returns a maximal PLO-set [12].
Given an archive A and a maximum size μ, a bounded archiving method, or archiver for short, will return a new archive A′ ⊆ A such that |A′| ≤ μ [7,9].

Here we focus on two archiving methods, hypervolume archiver (HVA) [6] and multi-level grid archiver (MGA) [8], which are the only known archiving methods belonging to the class with the most desirable convergence properties [9].

In particular, the exponential increase in the PLO-set size with lower objective correlation has already been reported for the bi-objective QAP [13].

Our experiments also strongly indicate that the relationship between local search length and number of local optima, which is well-studied in the single-objective case [5] and in the case of PLO-solutions [14], also applies to PLS and PLO-sets.

Finally, we left for future work discussing the implications of the results reported here with respect to theoretical bounds reported in the literature [2].

metadata.abstractText: The properties of local optimal solutions in multi-objective combinatorial optimization problems are crucial for the effectiveness of local search algorithms, particularly when these algorithms are based on Pareto dominance. Such local search algorithms typically return a set of mutually nondominated Pareto local optimal (PLO) solutions, that is, a PLO-set. This paper investigates two aspects of PLO-sets by means of experiments with Pareto local search (PLS). First, we examine the impact of several problem characteristics on the properties of PLO-sets for multi-objective NK-landscapes with correlated objectives. In particular, we report that either increasing the number of objectives or decreasing the correlation between objectives leads to an exponential increment on the size of PLO-sets, whereas the variable correlation has only a minor effect. Second, we study the running time and the quality reached when using bounding archiving methods to limit the size of the archive handled by PLS, and thus, the maximum size of the PLO-set found. We argue that there is a clear relationship between the running time of PLS and the difficulty of a problem instance.
